awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Understanding Arctic as a System
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will contribute toward building research capacity of future arctic science through teaching and training of undergraduate students in collaboration with an interdisciplinary team actively involved in Arctic system research. Students will bring the acquired experience back to their communities and spread the message about the exciting science that is done in the Arctic. Focusing on under-represented minorities will help broaden the base of the future arctic science workforce. Interdisciplinary educational materials that result from the summer experiences will be made available to a broad scientific community. 

The Arctic climate is changing and an integrated cross-disciplinary approach is needed to understand and explain changes in the Arctic and their implications. Researchers at the University of Alaska Fairbanks will establish a new REU site to attract undergraduates, including students from minority groups, to arctic sciences. The overarching goal of the project is to disseminate new knowledge and discoveries at the frontiers of polar science and ignite the enthusiasm of the undergraduates about the Arctic, thus contributing to the development of a diverse and environmentally educated U.S. science and engineering workforce. The science focus of this program will be on understanding Arctic as a system with emphasis on its physical components. The goals will be achieved by organizing summer research experience for undergraduates during which students will be involved in research and educational projects with their mentors and take advantage of collaboration with the proposing team. Pre- and post- summer experience surveys will provide metrics of success. 

The intellectual merit of this effort lies in focusing on the interdisciplinarity and the systems approach to understanding the Arctic environment. The proposed program of summer experience will provide the participating students with the current state of knowledge about the Arctic. The students will benefit from close interaction with their mentors who are actively involved in ongoing research and fieldwork in their disciplines. While each student (or group of students) will be involved in a separate project, they will be also provided with a broad context of Arctic system science. In addition to regular classroom teaching students will be involved in field trips and hands-on activities linked to research projects of their mentors. Each of the summer visits to Fairbanks will culminate in a workshop and a discussion between students and instructors, in which the students will present their results and will have an opportunity to synthesize about current problems of Arctic climate.

por.por_cntn:
Five summer programs were organized in 2017-2022 by the International Arctic Research Center (IARC) at the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) in collaboration with other institutes at UAF and other institutions, including government agencies. (2020 was a gap year due to COVID-19). A total of 30 students participated in the five summer programs. During the final year of the program (2022) we had only one student because of the limited remaining funding. Each summer program consisted of mentor-led individual research projects, a series of lectures, and field trips during the 9-week program. Each student worked as a member of a lab supervised by one or two UAF faculty members, and presented their own research results in a mini-conference at the end of the course. Most of the students (all except one) chose to present their results at national and international scientific conferences. Mentor-led projects resulted in 8 peer-reviewed publications in top scientific journals. The project also contributed to organizing an NSF-supported workshop ?Engaging Rural and Alaska Native Undergraduates and Youth in Arctic STEM''.

Our REU program has become very popular: the total number of applicants exceeded 400 over the four years of the full-scale program, with the highest number of student applications (165) in 2019, the final pre-COVID year.

2017: Eight students participated in a 9-week program with two visiting NOAA Hollings Scholars at IARC conducting their program simultaneously. All students participated in the lecture program and field trips to Toolik Lake Field Station, the local Permafrost Tunnel, Poker Flats Research Range, Gulkana Glacier. All students presented their results at a mini-symposium at IARC at the end of the course.

2018:  Eight NSF-supported plus one NOAA-supported student were a part of the 9-week program at IARC with visits to the research sites listed above. All students presented their results at a mini-symposium at IARC at the end of the course.

2019: The NSF-supported REU program was coordinated with a NOAA-supported Partnership for Education Program (NOAA Fisheries, AK Region). Eight NSF-supported students and five NOAA-supported students spent the first 3 weeks on lectures at IARC and research site visits. All students presented their results at a mini-symposium at IARC at the end of the course.

2020: The program was canceled due to COVID-19.

2021: Five NSF-supported students participated in the 9-week program. Two NOAA Hollings Scholars were visiting IARC simultaneously and occasionally participated in REU activities. Students participated in the lecture program and field trips to Toolik Lake Field Station, the Permafrost Tunnel, Poker Flats Research Range, and Gulkana Glacier. All students presented their results at a mini-symposium at IARC at the end of the course. The project contributed to an NSF-supported workshop on identifying barriers to engaging Alaska Native and rural students into STEM fields.

2022: One UAF undergraduate student (identified as Alaska Native) was employed to conduct a summer research project on precipitation and its importance for arctic hydrology.

An education specialist conducted pre-surveys before and post-surveys after each summer program.

Participants reported significant gains (p<.05) in the categories of locating and understanding primary research literature, and working with others to investigate and discuss a research problem. In addition there was a significant gain in overall knowledge about the Arctic and Arctic research (p< .03). More than 85% of participants reported that they will make an effort to continue research and plan to stay in contact with the scientists and co-workers from REU.

All participants agreed and strongly agreed that their summer REU project was interesting, that they learned skills they will use to achieve their career goals, and that collaboration and networking during REU were important. 

Housing, food and interaction with researchers was rated highly satisfied and satisfied by all participants.

Overall, our 2017-2022 REU summer program received very high ratings. All participants reported learning gains, increased interest in scientific research and careers in sciences. The detailed survey responses are available on request.

The young scientists who participated in our summer schools fully recognized and appreciated the value and the challenges of obtaining in-situ field data and modeling of the components of the Arctic System.  As these scientists advance in their careers, they will be in positions to develop observing strategies, modeling and measurement programs, thereby bringing their experience to bear on maximizing the efficiency of the observational infrastructure for the Arctic and modeling products. Measurements, including data collected with student assistance, provide a clearer understanding of how observational science is done.  Lectures provide background and solid theoretical support for the hands-on activities of the summer schools.  All pre-and post-event tests conducted by the education specialist indicated that students left with an improved understanding of the state of the art of arctic science.

Eight articles based on student projects have been published in top peer-reviewed scientific journals.
